Posts.Content: I've read that you should limit or avoid caffeine and alcohol. But feel free to drink as much water as you want. In the end, i am not sure there is clear advice on this and it varies by individual. Once a day for Keagels as Highlander suggest should be good. I also believe in stopping your urine flow when peeing a couple of times. I am also a believer that doing exercises that help build core strength (Google Core Strengthening Exercises) helps as well. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: I agree with Walnut and Baz, if I had gone the AS route I would have asked for the MRI before getting a biopsy. Out of the NCCN guidelines for those folks at low risk on AS: "Repeat prostate biopsy no more often than every twelve mo unless clinically indicated" The MRI can help determine if a biopsy is clinically indicated. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Bladder Spasm?

Posts.Content: How many PSA tests have you had? Do you remember the results? Did the doc do a DRE and what was the results? If you have been on T for a year, you should have been getting PSA tests no less than every six months (at your age). In any case, what does your doc say about your PSA? Were you riding a bike, have sex or masturbate, and/or have the DRE right before the PSA test? These can elevate PSA. Also, it could be other things like benign prostatitis or BPH. Probably need a little more info. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Hi Jeff, Here is a list of surgeons that I put together after doing a lot of reading, research and discussions with surgeons (with help from a list njs put together). Most of the criteria is based around number of surgeries and their record with getting a trifecta (Cure, ED & Incontinence). There are MANY qualified surgeons that have done over 1000 surgeries (my number is higher than Chucks . In the end, I went with Tewari in NYC... could not have done better IMHO. Many of the surgeons have their email published on their site and will email you back... and many will talk with you on the phone (it was a bit surreal when I realized I was chatting with these world renowned surgeons). Having this type of access and conversation was one of the ways I narrowed my list. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: I think everyone is a bit anxious as the time for surgery draws near including asking themselves "is this what I really want to do?" Try to relax and do what you normally do and take comfort in the fact you are taking action to get rid of the cancer. As far as suggestions, some folks will say to practice Kegals now... but I did not do that, instead, a couple weeks before surgery, whenever I took a piss I would stop the flow two or three times. Not sure it helped, but it certainly appears to not have hurt. Hang in there and Good Luck!

Can't wait till I can have a REAL meal!

Posts.Title: Post Op - Day 1

Posts.Content: Thanks! Day 2: Passed gas (Great Feeling!) and bowel movement. Had a scrambled egg and piece of toast as a reward... man was that good! Feeling pretty good today. Last night was a bit tough. Trying to get used to the catheter, finding a comfortable position and getting the bed just right. Slept in 2 hour blocks and got up and paced the living room for 30min in between, but overall did pretty good. Took a shower this morning... AHhhhhh... so good! Speaking of bed, if anyone comes to NYC for any reason, I highly recommend the Kimberly Hotel. They have been absolutely wonderful in helping me. They even have the most comfortable reclining beds (like hospital beds). Makes it SO much easier to get in and out of bed. Along with a kitchenette and VERY affordable LARGE one bedroom suite, it has made this experience so much easier.

Posts.Content: Hi n....., The others have pretty much summed it up. There are other advanced imaging tests (e.g., MRI with rectal coil or Color Doppler ultrasound) that can be performed prior to a biopsy that will either help with indications of PC and/or help target the biopsy. But finding these locations, getting insurance approval and determining how much they really help is all up in the air to some degree. Best bet (IMHO) is to go forward with the biopsy and based on that result determine what to do next. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Best post surgery pads

Posts.Content: I think it is a great idea but not widely done. There have been some studies and recent articles about it that show the benefits. The question that has to be asked is: Will it help make better treatment decisions by better identifying men with non-indolent cancer... over current practice? It certainly should help better cancer identification in the biopsy process... but then what? A scenario: An MRI is performed identifying a potential 1cm mass on the left lobe. To get the best chance of knowing the Gleason Score they put 4 needles out of 12 and only those 4 needles come back positive and the final score is G6 with low % involvement. Now what... is he considered Very Low or Low risk? Does it affect the treatment decision? I don't know. As a patient, I would certainly feel better with this additional information but I am not sure the insurance is going to pay for a MRI just to make me feel better (unfortunately, economics plays a role).

Posts.Title: MRI prior to biopsy?

Posts.Content: Hi n....., The others have pretty much summed it up. There are other advanced imaging tests (e.g., MRI with rectal coil or Color Doppler ultrasound) that can be performed prior to a biopsy that will either help with indications of PC and/or help target the biopsy. But finding these locations, getting insurance approval and determining how much they really help is all up in the air to some degree. Best bet (IMHO) is to go forward with the biopsy and based on that result determine what to do next. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: New Member w/Rising PSA

Posts.Content: Hi NightHiker, Sorry to hear your biopsy came back worse than before. First thing I would do is get a second opinion just to make sure it is a 3+4 (it's not clear if you have already done this). If it is, then you have made the right decision (IMHO). You have to pick a trigger otherwise you run the risk convincing yourself to continue AS. The NCCN guidelines say anything above G6 at your age should be treated (look at my sig for link). There is a little ambiguity in the guidelines, but it is pretty clear to me based on your age. As far as putting cancer behind me... yes, I don't think much about it anymore until my calendar pops up my next PSA test appointment. Other than that, I just like to keep checking in on this forum to help others (pay forward). I think everyone gets a little apprehensive in the final weeks and days before surgery, but it sounds like you picked a good surgeon so have confidence in him. Good luck and wishing you all the best!

Posts.Content: Hi Robert, the others have pretty much summed it up. When I was looking at surgery I talked to a doctor that does open (Dr. Burnett at John Hopkins) and a couple that due RALP (Dr. Tewari in NYC). Both had very similar numbers for ED, Incontinence and positive margin. Burnett also claims he can do everything through a single 3" incision and get similar recovery times (though he admits it might be a few days longer). So, it really comes down to the surgeon, not the method.

Posts.Content: Hi Barry, 5.1 is on the high end of reference ranges (based on age), but certainly not alarming for a 69 YO. What was your PSA from 2 years ago and other years? Also, did the doctor do a DRE and give you feedback on what he felt? You may want to go to a Urologist as a follow up... depending how comfortable you are with how knowledgeable the GP is with PC. As was mentioned, there are several benign reasons for elevated PSA (including if he did a DRE before the PSA blood work). What advice did the GP give you?

Posts.Title: Need advice please

Posts.Content: It really just comes down to the surgeon you choose. If you go open and pick someone at the level of Dr. Burnett at John Hopkins then open is just as good as RALP by many other surgeons. I almost went with Dr. Burnett but changed to Dr. Tewari after talking with him. It was just a personal choice (Dr. Burnett's recovery times rival RALP). Both doctors spent their own time with me on the phone at night and made me feel very comfortable. Sounds like you are going to talk to a few as well, that should really help with your decision. Good Luck.

Posts.Title: 60 Minute Erections

Posts.Content: Hey Tiger, glad to hear most everything is going pretty well... especially membership to the Zero Club. As far as injections, I find it to be really no big deal to inject and only takes less than a minute. The idea sounds worse than the actual act. Your doc will probably put you on either Bimix or Trimix (2 or 3 active ingredients) and start you off at a base dose. Once you try that you see how it works (how hard and how long) than you adjust the dosage. After 4 or 5 doses you should have it pretty well nailed down. I can pretty much nail it down so my erection lasts about 20 minutes though once in awhile I get a dud (I assume user injection error). I've never had an hour long erection since I crept up on the right dosage. But, the result of injections is amazing. Things happen right away (within minutes) and you are ready to go! You may also wan to consider getting the VED pump. Between the pump and injections I am almost at the point where I was before surgery. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Well... I suppose I need your advice.

Posts.Content: Hi Island, You can search through my threads to see what I did to research surgeons, including having phone calls with some of them (big names). I felt that given it is cancer and knowing the side effects I wanted one of the top surgeons to do it. If that meant traveling and paying for a two week stay at a hotel then so be it. That is why I picked Ash Tewari and traveled. JH surgeons are just as good and it all comes down to who you feel comfortable or connect with. I chose surgery over radiation: 1. Wanted to know the final pathology that you can only get after surgery 2. Found a surgeon that I trusted immensely 3. Worried about secondary treatment if the first was not successful 4. Wanted to deal with the side effects right off the bat versus wonder if they would get worse over time You also have the option of AS. We are similar in age and diagnosis... I chose treatment because my father is still alive and doing well at 84 (was just cutting down trees last weekend) therefore I have a pretty good chance of living another 30 years and did not want to take the small risk of cancer progression if I was on AS. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled

Posts.Content: As I continue my research and decision making process, I put together a preliminary list of potential surgeons should I elect to go this direction. Much, if not all, of these doctors were part of njs evaluation on this thread (thanks njs). The same surgeons keep coming up over and over so I finally got brain tired and stopped. Also, there is no question that one of these would be the right one for me. One of the criteria was that the surgeon had to have at least 1000 surgeries (not easy to find data on this) an be recommended by someone I could find with a Google search that used them for their surgery. If I missed someone, please let me and others know... I did focus more on the East Coast. If nothing else, I thought it might help others with their research. Posts.Title: Potential Surgeon List

Posts.Content: Haha... good question, kind of like you don't want the new car that was built on Friday afternoon. The article you published seems to indicate that there is no risk... which is good to know. When I had sinus surgery a couple years ago, I was scheduled as the last surgery (out of 4). The procedure before mine took 3 hours longer than planned and I did not even go into surgery until after 5pm. I joked with the doc about how tired he looked... he said "don't worry, I'll take a standing cat nap and eat my burrito in the OR while the anesthesiologist is putting you under". At the follow up appt, he said it was probably one of the best outcomes he has ever had (I guess the burrito and cat nap worked). Who knows what really goes on in the OR.

Posts.Title: Potential Surgeon List

Posts.Content: 2Fury, You are the youngest case I have heard of, and what is incredible is that you found out early enough that you have a high likelihood of a cure. Talk to your doctor, but I am not sure you will find any that say it is OK to go on AS. At your age, you have way to many years of natural life to risk taking a chance with AS, IMHO. With my robotic surgery, I was readily able to travel and do almost anything I did before at 4 weeks. At 6 weeks, I was cleared to go back to working out (lifting weights) at full strength. Everyone's case varies some with much of the recovery and side effects very dependent on the skill of the surgeon. Nobody can predict what level of incontinence or erectile dysfunction issues you may have. Some, like myself, have had very little issues... others go on for years. Your advantage is your age, which definitely works in your favor. Do take some time and do some research to gain an understanding of this cancer... it will better help with your decisions and ability to cope. Also, ask away with any questions... nothing is off limits and there is a wealth of experience that participates on this forum (like Chuck says, take it as a slanted view since opinions can vary greatly). Best of luck and keep us updated!

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled

Posts.Content: Haha... good question, kind of like you don't want the new car that was built on Friday afternoon. The article you published seems to indicate that there is no risk... which is good to know. When I had sinus surgery a couple years ago, I was scheduled as the last surgery (out of 4). The procedure before mine took 3 hours longer than planned and I did not even go into surgery until after 5pm. I joked with the doc about how tired he looked... he said "don't worry, I'll take a standing cat nap and eat my burrito in the OR while the anesthesiologist is putting you under". At the follow up appt, he said it was probably one of the best outcomes he has ever had (I guess the burrito and cat nap worked). Who knows what really goes on in the OR.

Posts.Content: 2Fury, You are the youngest case I have heard of, and what is incredible is that you found out early enough that you have a high likelihood of a cure. Talk to your doctor, but I am not sure you will find any that say it is OK to go on AS. At your age, you have way to many years of natural life to risk taking a chance with AS, IMHO. With my robotic surgery, I was readily able to travel and do almost anything I did before at 4 weeks. At 6 weeks, I was cleared to go back to working out (lifting weights) at full strength. Everyone's case varies some with much of the recovery and side effects very dependent on the skill of the surgeon. Nobody can predict what level of incontinence or erectile dysfunction issues you may have. Some, like myself, have had very little issues... others go on for years. Your advantage is your age, which definitely works in your favor. Do take some time and do some research to gain an understanding of this cancer... it will better help with your decisions and ability to cope. Also, ask away with any questions... nothing is off limits and there is a wealth of experience that participates on this forum (like Chuck says, take it as a slanted view since opinions can vary greatly). Best of luck and keep us updated!

Much, if not all, of these doctors were part of njs evaluation on this thread (thanks njs). The same surgeons keep coming up over and over so I finally got brain tired and stopped. Also, there is no question that one of these would be the right one for me. One of the criteria was that the surgeon had to have at least 1000 surgeries (not easy to find data on this) an be recommended by someone I could find with a Google search that used them for their surgery. If I missed someone, please let me and others know... I did focus more on the East Coast. If nothing else, I thought it might help others with their research. Posts.Content: Well it has been 2 weeks and thought I would give an update: - Final pathology: G6, 5% involvement, negative margins - Had some movement down there during first week, erection during this past week (though the alarms went off "Foreign body... Foreign body... shutdown" due to the catheter being there) - First catheter was removed a week ago, but had trouble taking a wiz (just drops and dribble... AND lots of pain!). Had to go to ER to get new catheter put in (they were in contact with doctor since the got a little anxious when I told them I just had surgery. - Got 2nd catheter out today (oh what a relief it is) and all is well. Had a pad on all day and it is still dry (even with all the coughing due to a cold). Will keep fingers crossed that this continues. - Except for the healing incisions, I feel and look as good (or bad) as I did before surgery Dr. Tewari and his staff are top notch. Even the PA who was text-ing me constantly on Sunday when I had the problem peeing. He said he was extremely confident that he got it all. The way he does it is by doing a MRI prior to surgery and then using that as a map to make his first cuts and removal of the prostate. After he removes it he takes several samples and gets an immediate pathology (while this is going on, he went out and talked to my wife). Based on this pathology, he decides if he needs to take more, which he did not need to do for me. All and all, extremely pleased with the results to date.

Posts.Title: Post Op - Two Weeks

Posts.Content: Hi Hogiebear.... Sorry to hear you have joined our little club. There is a wealth of info available here (recommend the stickies) and many members that can help. Can you share the details of your biopsy (number of cores, number of cores positive, % of each positive core)? That will help with the replies (you can see most of us put it in our signature). For Gleason 6 you may have various options with the three main types being radiation (few different types), surgery and Active Surveillance (AS). Should you end up going forward with treatment, I would also recommend you talk to both an experienced surgeon and a radiation oncologist. But, AS may be an option as well depending on your pathology report. I am a bit biased, but you have one of the top surgeons in the world right there in NYC (I traveled from FL to use him), Dr. Tewari. If you look at surgery, then you may want to talk to him. Finally, a G6 diagnosis means you have plenty of time to think about your decision... there is no rush. Research, ask questions, get comfortable with what YOU think is best for you. There are many here that can help and have done a great deal of research already... so ask away if you have questions. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Good question but many answers. I think you would find that doctors will differ somewhat on when to do a biopsy. Typically, one or a combination of: 1. History of increasing PSA 2. Positive finding on the DRE 3. MRI showing area of concern (not typically done today, but new technology is available) Others will chime in with their thoughts. Of course, you can always get a second opinion from another urologist.

Posts.Title: How would a patient doublecheck whether or not biopsy is needed or overprescribed?

Posts.Content: I thought I would give a quick update and probably my last one. I feel a bit guilty about writing this since others have had more issues than me, but I thought it would be important for others to hear about how well things can go. Bottom line, I am pretty much back to what I was pre-Op. I have not worn a pad in over a week, with zero leakage under any condition. I have erections that are pretty much no different than before and as often as before. My pee stream is at about 3/4 of what it was before (which was really good) and getting better every day. I have absolutely no pain and am off all medications. I do take 5mg of Cialis a day just to make sure things stay "active". I don't have a lot of scientific evidence to back this up, but I think my success is due to: Excellent surgeon Age Positive attitude Exercised 5 to 6 days a week prior to surgery Healthy diet Smaller prostate (better ability to spare/upset nerves) G6 low involvement (less to remove to get negative margins) Loving and supportive family, especially my beautiful wife Research and all I have learned from this site (Thanks!) Thanks again all for all the debate, support and excellent information! Mike

My wife just rolls her eyes.

Posts.Title: Post Op - Two Weeks

Posts.Content: Yep... both nerves were spared. I am holding my breath on incontinence and ED... but so far so good! I had a pounding headache after surgery so they gave me some Percocet. That did not work so they gave me some morphine... I threw up 30 seconds later but felt better. When my headache was still there 4 hours later, I told them to bring on the morphine... sure enough, threw up again. Did not care... I traded 30 seconds of vomit for hours of relief! Did it one more time later in the night. The worst for me was the Monday before surgery. I had a MRI, Bone Scan and CT all in the same day. Another pounding headache and had to stay perfectly still during those scans... I was hoping someone would just knock me out I was so miserable. Still not quite sure why I had the CT and Bone Scan (I think there was some last minute confusion), but they came back perfectly clean so it was good to know.

Posts.Title: Post Op - Two Weeks

Posts.Content: I thought I would give a quick update and probably my last one. I feel a bit guilty about writing this since others have had more issues than me, but I thought it would be important for others to hear about how well things can go. Bottom line, I am pretty much back to what I was pre-Op. I have not worn a pad in over a week, with zero leakage under any condition. I have erections that are pretty much no different than before and as often as before. My pee stream is at about 3/4 of what it was before (which was really good) and getting better every day. I have absolutely no pain and am off all medications. I do take 5mg of Cialis a day just to make sure things stay "active". I don't have a lot of scientific evidence to back this up, but I think my success is due to: Excellent surgeon Age Positive attitude Exercised 5 to 6 days a week prior to surgery Healthy diet Smaller prostate (better ability to spare/upset nerves) G6 low involvement (less to remove to get negative margins) Loving and supportive family, especially my beautiful wife Research and all I have learned from this site (Thanks!) Thanks again all for all the debate, support and excellent information! Mike

Posts.Title: 8 month Postop Visit

Posts.Content: Well it has been 2 weeks and thought I would give an update: - Final pathology: G6, 5% involvement, negative margins - Had some movement down there during first week, erection during this past week (though the alarms went off "Foreign body... Foreign body... shutdown" due to the catheter being there) - First catheter was removed a week ago, but had trouble taking a wiz (just drops and dribble... AND lots of pain!). Had to go to ER to get new catheter put in (they were in contact with doctor since the got a little anxious when I told them I just had surgery. - Got 2nd catheter out today (oh what a relief it is) and all is well. Had a pad on all day and it is still dry (even with all the coughing due to a cold). Will keep fingers crossed that this continues. - Except for the healing incisions, I feel and look as good (or bad) as I did before surgery Dr. Tewari and his staff are top notch. Even the PA who was text-ing me constantly on Sunday when I had the problem peeing. He said he was extremely confident that he got it all. The way he does it is by doing a MRI prior to surgery and then using that as a map to make his first cuts and removal of the prostate. After he removes it he takes several samples and gets an immediate pathology (while this is going on, he went out and talked to my wife). Based on this pathology, he decides if he needs to take more, which he did not need to do for me. All and all, extremely pleased with the results to date.

My wife just rolls her eyes.

Posts.Content: Congrats on the continued Zero Club Membership! Can't help much on the incontinence. But on ED you can read my recent update. If you are getting some movement then you may want to talk to your doc about a similar rehabilitation regime. The theory is that when you start artificially creating hard erections the nerves and all the associated parts will relearn and get exercised. It is definitely working for me. Guess I am not sure why someone would go directly to an implant before exhausting all the other options. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: 8 month Postop Visit

Posts.Content: By the end of the night you will be sick of drinking your meals and looking forward to getting to bed! Stay busy with other odd stuff (I played computer games for 8 hours). Tomorrow will happen pretty fast and before you know it you will be up and walking and kicked out of the hospital. Then walk, walk, walk as much as possible to help get that first fart out which leads to the bowel movement... THEN YOU CAN EAT! Good news, that first meal tastes SO good. I had a full breakfast (eggs, toast, hash browns, bacon, coffee and orange juice) at a diner. Good Luck and see you on the other side!

Posts.Content: You have to fast all day? I was on a Clear Liquid diet ( apple juice, clear soups and broths, coffee and tea without cream, clear gelatin, grape juice, cranberry juice, sodas, and popsicles) until midnight then nothing. The morning of surgery I think I had to drink a bottle of magnesium citrate. You may want to double check with your doctor. Best of Luck!

Posts.Title: My surgery is in a few days

Posts.Content: Hey Jeb, as others have said, I think you still have time to let things improve. I am sure it is difficult and frustrating but hang in there. Question, if you don't mind, I am curious when you take a piss, can stop your pee mid stream? Not sure this matters, but it is my own scientific mind thinking that the more you do this you develop muscle memory (really brain reflex memory) to do this when you leak. Again, unscientific, but this is what I did pre/post surgery instead of doing kegals. On the ED front, definitely go for the injections, IMHO. There is BiMix, TriMix and QuadMix (2-4 different mix of drugs). Your doctor will pick one of them and the ratio of the mix based on what he thinks will work the best. Most popular is TriMix, but I am on BiMix and it works great. Also, you may want to try the VED pump. Between the injections and the pump my spontaneous erections definitely improved. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Decision Made: Surgery, Dr. Tewari, 1/16

Posts.Content: Well, by preponderance of the evidence my prostate has been found guilty of having cancer and subject to a penalty of removal by surgery. After having read countless articles, studies, forum posts; talked to numerous doctors and, most importantly, talked with family and friends I have made the decision to have surgery. The decision was not made lightly, nor was there much emotion behind it... more of a numbers game with surgery giving me a slight edge IMHO. And as someone who loves to gamble, a slight edge can pay off over time. Plan is to fly up to NYC on the Sunday before, have a MRI on Monday, meet with Dr. Tewari on Tuesday and surgery on Thursday. Will stay up there until the catheter comes out then fly home. I had narrowed my potential surgeons down to three (Tewari, Burnett, Patel) and chose Tewari because he was just plain approachable and made me feel like I was his only patient... the same goes for his staff. Anyway... decision done... now on to the holidays and a two week vacation in NYC!

Posts.Content: Hey Kat! Good Luck tomorrow, to both of you! Dr. Tewari will probably talk to you halfway through the surgery when he is waiting for his quick pathology report on the samples he takes. You will probably get a pretty good feel for how things went at that point. I am pretty certain he only has one team (I am pretty sure I asked him this and remember the response of "Of Course!". We got 10" of snow when we were there and everything in NYC kept on ticking, so I don't expect that you will have problems. Be sure to leave enough time for the slower traffic (unless you are going in at 5AM like we did). Tell your husband I said "Hi" and to feel free to call me if he has any questions after surgery. We will be thinking of ya!

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing Question

Posts.Content: Make sure you get a Digital Rectal Exam (RE). If you had one, what were the results (what did the doctor feel)? Not sure what your hesitation is to getting a biopsy? It is pretty straightforward with minimal risk. Takes about 10 minutes and mine was done right in the office.

We will be thinking of ya!

Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: CyberKnife is high precision higher dose radiation. It is delivered by a robot in 5-7 sessions (so much less treatments then typical external beam) where the robot delivers the radiation around ~150-200 different angles and positions during each treatment. The prostate has gold markers that are used to image guide the robot in real time to make sure the radiation is being delivered accurately. The idea is that it provides increased accuracy in the delivery of the x-rays and therefore is more likely to spare surrounding tissue/organs. I considered this for treatment but decided against it due to the higher dose and relatively low amount of information long term side effects.

Posts.Title: Advice needed on getting or not getting a Biopsy on prostate

Posts.Content: 44, 3.5, 9%... I would ask to be tested again sooner or go to another uro to get another opinion. If you did not get a DRE, then you need to... if you did, what were the results. Some would argue that at your age, with those numbers, it would trigger a biopsy. But like others have said, PCa is very slow so waiting another 2-4 month to rule out other causes for increasing your PSA is not a bad idea. Worse case, after a couple of months and if you can afford it, you can order an online test and and bring the order to a lab (in my case it is the same lab my doc uses)... but it does not sound you really need to rush.

Posts.Content: The only way to determine PC for sure is by a pathologist examining prostate tissue... therefore a biopsy is required. The MRI can help determine the risk along with helping guide where the biopsy samples may be taken, but it cannot validate that PC exists. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Husbands surgery tomorrow

Posts.Content: Based on what I know and have read, PSA can bounce around a little. Mine went from 4.5 to 3.4 to 4.6 within 6 months. So it is hard to get a read as to whether it is really increasing. But you are consistently over so I would be concerned... heck, I was concerned after 3 tests. From what I have read there is a slight chance... sounds like on the order of a couple percent... that cancer could get into the blood stream but it is not likely to live there long. The trade off is not doing it, having cancer that spreads to other organs... then you are in a much worse position. I personally think the trade off is worth it. For me, the biopsy was no different than giving blood. I had my wife with me, but I am certain I could have driven after. I've read where some folks have taken a pain med prior the biopsy (based on mine, I don't see the need) and therefore I would not recommend driving if you take pain med. [note... this raises an interesting question as to why PSA tests are not done more often. For the cost (~$40) it seems like the extra data would yield a better prediction curve]

Posts.Title: Questions to ask surgeon

Posts.Content: Hi Barry... you may want to get a second opinion on the biopsy. Your uro may know of someone or you can have him send it to John Hopkins. Also given no findings on the DRE any treatment you may decide to go with should have an excellent chance of success. But if a second opinion comes back as a 3+3 it means you may also have the alternative of AS. In any case, it sounds like you have some time to absorb and learn that the best choice is for you. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: I did the same as Chuck, flew in 3 days before and stayed 10 days after. I wanted to get the catheter out while near the doc and he did a test for leakage prior to removing the catheter. Could not imagine being in a car after surgery, especially if you are bloated or still not having your first bowel movement. I did consider coming back earlier, but made a vacation out of it (as best I could) since I was in NYC with my wife.

Posts.Title: Final Days

Posts.Content: Hi Dan, First, I would get another read on the biopsy slides. You can have your uro send them somewhere, I had mine sent to John Hopkins, instructions here. This way you are sure it is a 3+4 and not something worse or better. Your uro should have no issue with this. As lancepeace said, you need not be in any big rush... take some time and research surgery and radiation. Others might comment on other treatment options. I is also helpful to look at the NCCN guidelines as they are recommendations from a group of cancer centers around the world. The book by Patrick Walsh is also recommended. It is an easy read and goes over everything you might want to know. My take on everything I have read, for your age and score, is that your best bet is surgery since you can get radiation later if surgery is not fully successful. But it is not always a good option the other way around. Active Surveillance is also still an option, but you are right on the fringe of being able to to that IMHO. There are pros and cons to Surgery and Radiation. In general, the side effects with surgery are immediate and usually get better. The side effects with radiation are better right after treatment but can get worse with time. That is why I think surgery might be a better option. In the end, it is really a personal decision based on the quality of life objectives and understanding of the risks of whatever path you take. That is why you should do research and only take what you read on here as input to augment that research (everyone will be a bit biased based on their own personal situation). Good Luck and continue to ask questions and keep us informed!

Posts.Content: Hi Mark... Did you go to your urologist? Did the ER just put a catheter in or did they do any tests? I definitely pee better now than before my surgery. Not sure how long it takes (I'll time it next time) but the stream is plenty strong and when it stops I give it the obligatory couple of shakes and I am done. A quick search shows that a male, 45 to 65, should have a flow of 12 mL/sec. You can look up Uroflowmetry as a test which gives you and indication of your flow over time. I may try a homemade version of this to see what kind of numbers I get. It is possible you have some scaring that is blocking at the bladder/urethra connection made by the surgeon. In any case, I would recommend you go to your uro. Good Luck and keep us updated!

Posts.Content: Welcome... sorry for your concern. I am certainly no expert as well but I have some questions/thoughts... How many biopsies have you had? It sounds like you have enough MRI information to do a targeted biopsy at this point and get a good read on the aggressiveness of the tumor. Although the MRI data you show above indicate 3 lesions. The previous MRI finds one Posterolateral (side/back) 14mm from mid-line (that is why I say side first in side/back) and the latest finds one Anteromedial (front/side) with one side at the mid-line (therefore front is first). This would indicate to me two separate areas of concern? What does your doctor say/recommend about this latest MRI? Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Phoenix area surgeon recommendations?

Posts.Content: Yes, I was on T when I was diagnosed 15 months ago. I immediately stopped at that point. My local uro (he did not do my surgery) felt the way I did about the risk and agreed that after three months post surgery if my PSA was undetectable I could restart T... which I did... with the agreement that I get tested every three months (PSA, T level and CBC [make sure my Hematocrit stays acceptable]). I feel your pain about going off T. I was hit pretty hard when I went off with similar symptoms. It did get a little better after a few months when my body starting generating some T on it's own, but my levels were still low.

Posts.Content: It's only been 4 months for me, but my surgeon told me it was for life. I think they like to keep track of their patients so that they can maintain their database for the long term. Has not been a problem for me... my local uro handles all the tests (since surgeon is 1200 miles away) and they get sent to the surgeon.

Posts.Title: How long does contact with surgeon last?

Posts.Content: Been a while since I have posted (life kinda got in the way) but thought I would give an update. PSA: Undetectable Testosterone: Still on 80mgs IM per week Incontinence: Still nothing to speak of. A drop here or there while working out, pushing out a fart, or laughing hard. ED: After getting to ~75% of where I was pre-Op I stalled. So I am currently on a rehabilitation plan: - 5 mg Cialis/Day (backing off to every other day) - 2 EDOX Cardio tablets per day - Pump(VED) everyday. Hold suction for one min, off for one minute, repeat 3-5 times - Viagra 100-200mgs twice a week - Bimix: ~0.2ml 2-3 times per week I have to say the Bimix is a wonder drug. Doing the injection is no issue for me, but the results (and resulting sex) is amazing. I've been doing all this for about a month now and the number and firmness of my spontaneous erections has increased significantly (night time or morning wood). Doc said I can start backing off if everything continues after another month and would like me to be off everything but Cialis in under 6 months (or less). Will keep my fingers crossed. Other: My orgasms have not changed or may have gotten a little more intense. The lack of ejaculation has taken some time to get past. I do still miss that part, but not enough to let it bother me or interfere. Exercise: I workout (weights) 3-5 times per week and watch my calories and nutrition balance (carbs, fat, protein)... I think this has been a big help in my overall feeling. Though I still hate cardio so only do it 10 min per workout. Finally, my wife has been incredibly patient, helpful and understanding during this whole process... I love her dearly.
Posts.Signature: Age 60, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 230# 2013 PSA Jan:4.5, Mar:3.4, Jul:4.6, Oct:8.1, Nov:7.7 Normal DRE 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 09/24/2013 John Hopkins Pathology: 2/12, 5% & 10%, G3+3, 2 HGPIN 01/16/2014 RALP by Dr. Tewari, Final Path: G6, 5% involvement, neg Margins No incontinence, minimal ED issues after two weeks post-op NICE Guidance & NCCN Guidance
Posts.Title: Update: 9 months post RALP

Posts.Content: I have no prostate, but still, T after RALP is a bit controversial. There is concern by some docs that there could be cancer cells left and T will feed them but others that think risk is minimal. I had a low Gleason disease and pretty confident it was all taken out. Also, I tend to agree with the research that T levels above a pretty low number have no further affect... So boosting T levels does not increase the risk. I would not advise anyone else to do this without doing their own research and making their own decision. If I had done AS, drugs or even radiation, I would not be on T now.

Posts.Content: Everyone is different on how well they recover. I felt great after two weeks, though restricted from lifting over 10 lbs for another 4 weeks. Others have had a much longer recovery. Is he in relatively good shape? Has he had previous surgeries... how well did he recover? I think these are indicators to how he might potentially recover from this surgery. Good luck to you and your husband... keep us updated!

Posts.Title: I am now Prostate free :)

Posts.Content: Your story is an example of making sure you research who you want to do your surgery. That is why I picked who I did... I knew I would get his cell phone number (he gave it to me before surgery) and his PA gave me her work and personal cell number. I also had to have the catheter put back in on a Sunday and my surgeon was 1200 miles away. BUT, the PA called the emergency room and walked them through exactly what they needed to do. Prior to that she was trading text messages with me all weekend monitoring my urinary progress and told me when it was time to go to the ER. I truly hope things get better quickly for your husband (and you)!

Posts.Title: What nobody told before surgery

Posts.Content: It's only been 4 months for me, but my surgeon told me it was for life. I think they like to keep track of their patients so that they can maintain their database for the long term. Has not been a problem for me... my local uro handles all the tests (since surgeon is 1200 miles away) and they get sent to the surgeon.

Posts.Title: I am now Prostate free :)

Posts.Content: IMHO, you have to pick a number that makes you feel comfortable that the surgeon is past the learning curve and has come across various complications AND has enough history to be meaningful when you ask questions. For me, this was 1000. Then you can ask all the questions about outcomes (ED, incontinence, positive margins, etc.) to get a feel for the likelihood of a trifecta for someone with your conditions. As with other decisions around PC, there is probably no real wrong answer, just whatever makes you feel good and gives you the most confidence about the potential outcome.

Posts.Title: How to researh

Posts.Content: Given the amount of discussion around AS versus treatment in the various threads, I thought it might be useful to have that discussion in a thread of its own. This way we are not commandeering someone elses thread. Dont think of this as Miklas thread, think of this as a neutral ground debate thread. ALL opinions are welcome, spirited debate is welcome, point/counterpoint arguments are encouraged. We should show as much respect as possible, but everyone has to understand that there is a great deal of emotions behind the topic so only read and post if you have a thick skin. In other words, we should all be able to go out for a beer (or your beverage of choice) at the end of the day. I urge everyone to participate, even those that are lurking who might have questions or opinions. Highlander will monitor the thread and as the admin and will step in where necessary (along with posting his own thoughts). So Buddy(Bud) Iamanonymous is our imaginary friend. He is tipping over the line to have surgery versus Active Surveillance (AS) and is looking for help to either push him over or pull him back to AS. History: Age 55, 6'2", 230# 01/11/2013 PSA 4.5 01/28/2013 DRE Normal, "slightly enlarged" 03/21/2013 PSA 3.4 07/26/2013 PSA 4.6 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 09/24/2013 John Hopkins Pathology: 2/12, 5% & 10%, G3+3, 2 HGPIN 10/03/2013 2nd Opinion, DRE normal, agrees with options (surgery, radiation or AS) 10/25/2013 PSA 8.1 11/04/2013 PSA 7.7 Assumptions: Putting PCa aside, Bud will live for 30 more years (in other words, not die from any other cause) based on family history and link Bud is a close friend to all of us, so we all have his best interest at heart Bud is not here to discuss his position but ask that I take the lead and clear up any assumptions for him He is not a worry wart, instead he is able to be very objective His quality of life (QoL) objectives are to 1) live a long time, 2) take care of his family, 3)be happy, 4)be financially secure His goals for dealing with PCa are 1)live a long time, 2) maintain his QoL, 3) minimizing long term side effects ([a] recurrence if treated, [b] erectile dysfunction, [c] bowel problems, [d] incontinence). His current state in some side effect areas is 1) ED: Some problems, 2) bowel: excellent, 3) incontinence: excellent His reasons and position for leaning toward surgery: He definitely wants to live another 30 years Based on Partin Tables, 20% of men with G6 PCa have a higher grade decease found after surgery and his chance of extraprostatic extension (beyond the prostate) are 18% link. Based on his latest PSA and the fact he has two HGPIN at biopsy indicates his chances of having G7+ are even greater. NCCN states that one of the criteria for AS is to have <20 yrs of life expectancy link: see PROS-B. This is also stated in the guidelines by John Hopkins link He has ruled out radiation: Some studies have shown that radiation side effects get worse with time, not better. link Reoccurrence treatment options are limited with radiation (salvage surgery is more difficult) link. Some side effects can be worse than the original problem (radiation cystitis or proctitis). Some studies show that long term survival after radiation is not much better than AS link. His rise in PSA is concerning. While it could be something else benign, he has no symptoms of prostatitis. If PCa caused, then this doubling time is well beyond most limits for AS. link Several studies show that the mortality rate are improved by ~5% at 15 years for men that choose surgery versus AS It is easier to recover from surgery at a younger age and the surgical risks are lower link link Even with AS and all the PSA tests and biopsies, there is no clear tipping point on when to get treatment (studies appear to be all over the map on this), if at all so why bother to even monitor it. link For men with long life expectancies, AS is putting of the inevitable treatment. Trading potential (because there could be none or minimal) side effects of treatment, for shorter term perceived gain. 30% of those on AS will have cancer progression within 5 years link Any future curative procedures or solutions will not have historical data to support any claims of being better than what is available today with surgery While there are studies that indicate G3 cells will not advance to G4 cells, these studies are still a bit inconclusive link There are other studies that conclude that the PCa does evolve to higher levels over time link link link. So while there appears to be no conclusive evidence at this time, there is some basis that indicates PCa does evolve so why wait? So there it is, feel free to jump in and help Bud by either refuting or supporting his position.

Posts.Content: Haha... yeah, Bud and I swear we are identical twins, but our mothers (who look remarkably similar) say we are not... In his position, Bud alludes to any future treatment will not have enough supporting data to conclusively determine if it is better than surgery. I would support that by saying if there is some better treatment in the works we would know about it now such that it had time to gain some history before those on AS would need to or go that direction.

Posts.Title: DEBATE: Talk Bud (G6) out of Surgery - Warning: Content may not be for the meek

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigbrad2008 I won't attack Mikla, but can I pick on his twin called Bud? Think of him as my evil look-alike that has gotten me in trouble by pretending to be me... he is fair game as far as I am concerned. Your right about the lack of definitive research. As you say, PCa is slow growing and the prostate is in a very difficult place making direct observation through a scope nearly impossible. There are lots of trade offs between radiation and surgery. Incontinence has certainly shown to be better with radiation, but ED appears to be about the same over time depending on how much ED you had pre-treatment (with radiation getting a slight edge). But you run the risk of bowel problems with radiation along with not getting some definitive answers on the progression of the disease. Then again, as you say for your condition, if it is outside the prostate then you might end up getting radiation anyway. So radiation vs surgery seems to come down to what fits your needs. It sounds like you picked the perfect treatment for your situation.

Posts.Content: Hey Tazz... you should read the sticky on Divinci surgery along with the ones on incontinence and ED. Here is a list of some of the top surgeons I put together. There are many more beyond this.... One of the criteria I used was 1000+ surgeries. As far as ED and Incontinence, everyone is different. Some have significant problems and some have very little... I had very little issues. I would suggest if you choose surgery, that you assume you will have some problems. Make sure to ask any surgeons you talk to what there success rate is for your type of condition and Gleason score. Best of luck!

Posts.Title: How do you choose the right surgeon and hospital to perform a daVinci Prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Hey Joe, Hard to predict without a biopsy, thought Walnut may chime in about his experience with a type of MRI. Looking at just your PSA, your doubling time is about 35 months and your PSA velocity is 1.86 ng/ml/yr. There is still some debate on whether either of these is a good predictor to prostate cancer. Reference: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/di.../psa-velocity/ But with the family history and your trending PSA you do have an increased risk (IMHO). Of course, this is complicated, as has already been said, there are other benign causes of increased PSA (e.g., BPH and infection). Others will chime in and please post your biopsy results.

Posts.Title: Post Op Progress

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigbrad2008 I won't attack Mikla, but can I pick on his twin called Bud? Think of him as my evil look-alike that has gotten me in trouble by pretending to be me... he is fair game as far as I am concerned. Your right about the lack of definitive research. As you say, PCa is slow growing and the prostate is in a very difficult place making direct observation through a scope nearly impossible. There are lots of trade offs between radiation and surgery. Incontinence has certainly shown to be better with radiation, but ED appears to be about the same over time depending on how much ED you had pre-treatment (with radiation getting a slight edge). But you run the risk of bowel problems with radiation along with not getting some definitive answers on the progression of the disease. Then again, as you say for your condition, if it is outside the prostate then you might end up getting radiation anyway. So radiation vs surgery seems to come down to what fits your needs. It sounds like you picked the perfect treatment for your situation.

Posts.Title: DEBATE: Talk Bud (G6) out of Surgery - Warning: Content may not be for the meek

Posts.Content: Given the amount of discussion around AS versus treatment in the various threads, I thought it might be useful to have that discussion in a thread of its own. This way we are not commandeering someone elses thread. Dont think of this as Miklas thread, think of this as a neutral ground debate thread. ALL opinions are welcome, spirited debate is welcome, point/counterpoint arguments are encouraged. We should show as much respect as possible, but everyone has to understand that there is a great deal of emotions behind the topic so only read and post if you have a thick skin. In other words, we should all be able to go out for a beer (or your beverage of choice) at the end of the day. I urge everyone to participate, even those that are lurking who might have questions or opinions. Highlander will monitor the thread and as the admin and will step in where necessary (along with posting his own thoughts). So Buddy(Bud) Iamanonymous is our imaginary friend. He is tipping over the line to have surgery versus Active Surveillance (AS) and is looking for help to either push him over or pull him back to AS. History: Age 55, 6'2", 230# 01/11/2013 PSA 4.5 01/28/2013 DRE Normal, "slightly enlarged" 03/21/2013 PSA 3.4 07/26/2013 PSA 4.6 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 09/24/2013 John Hopkins Pathology: 2/12, 5% & 10%, G3+3, 2 HGPIN 10/03/2013 2nd Opinion, DRE normal, agrees with options (surgery, radiation or AS) 10/25/2013 PSA 8.1 11/04/2013 PSA 7.7 Assumptions: Putting PCa aside, Bud will live for 30 more years (in other words, not die from any other cause) based on family history and link Bud is a close friend to all of us, so we all have his best interest at heart Bud is not here to discuss his position but ask that I take the lead and clear up any assumptions for him He is not a worry wart, instead he is able to be very objective His quality of life (QoL) objectives are to 1) live a long time, 2) take care of his family, 3)be happy, 4)be financially secure His goals for dealing with PCa are 1)live a long time, 2) maintain his QoL, 3) minimizing long term side effects ([a] recurrence if treated, [b] erectile dysfunction, [c] bowel problems, [d] incontinence). His current state in some side effect areas is 1) ED: Some problems, 2) bowel: excellent, 3) incontinence: excellent His reasons and position for leaning toward surgery: He definitely wants to live another 30 years Based on Partin Tables, 20% of men with G6 PCa have a higher grade decease found after surgery and his chance of extraprostatic extension (beyond the prostate) are 18% link. Based on his latest PSA and the fact he has two HGPIN at biopsy indicates his chances of having G7+ are even greater. NCCN states that one of the criteria for AS is to have <20 yrs of life expectancy link: see PROS-B. This is also stated in the guidelines by John Hopkins link He has ruled out radiation: Some studies have shown that radiation side effects get worse with time, not better. link Reoccurrence treatment options are limited with radiation (salvage surgery is more difficult) link. Some side effects can be worse than the original problem (radiation cystitis or proctitis). Some studies show that long term survival after radiation is not much better than AS link. His rise in PSA is concerning. While it could be something else benign, he has no symptoms of prostatitis. If PCa caused, then this doubling time is well beyond most limits for AS. link Several studies show that the mortality rate are improved by ~5% at 15 years for men that choose surgery versus AS It is easier to recover from surgery at a younger age and the surgical risks are lower link link Even with AS and all the PSA tests and biopsies, there is no clear tipping point on when to get treatment (studies appear to be all over the map on this), if at all so why bother to even monitor it. link For men with long life expectancies, AS is putting of the inevitable treatment. Trading potential (because there could be none or minimal) side effects of treatment, for shorter term perceived gain. 30% of those on AS will have cancer progression within 5 years link Any future curative procedures or solutions will not have historical data to support any claims of being better than what is available today with surgery While there are studies that indicate G3 cells will not advance to G4 cells, these studies are still a bit inconclusive link There are other studies that conclude that the PCa does evolve to higher levels over time link link link. So while there appears to be no conclusive evidence at this time, there is some basis that indicates PCa does evolve so why wait? So there it is, feel free to jump in and help Bud by either refuting or supporting his position.
Posts.Signature: Age 60, DOB 11/1957, 6'2", 230# 2013 PSA Jan:4.5, Mar:3.4, Jul:4.6, Oct:8.1, Nov:7.7 Normal DRE 08/29/2013 Biopsy: 2/12 positive (RLM,RLA), <5%/core, Gleason 3+3 09/24/2013 John Hopkins Pathology: 2/12, 5% & 10%, G3+3, 2 HGPIN 01/16/2014 RALP by Dr. Tewari, Final Path: G6, 5% involvement, neg Margins No incontinence, minimal ED issues after two weeks post-op NICE Guidance & NCCN Guidance
Posts.Title: DEBATE: Talk Bud (G6) out of Surgery - Warning: Content may not be for the meek

Posts.Content: Haha... yeah, Bud and I swear we are identical twins, but our mothers (who look remarkably similar) say we are not... In his position, Bud alludes to any future treatment will not have enough supporting data to conclusively determine if it is better than surgery. I would support that by saying if there is some better treatment in the works we would know about it now such that it had time to gain some history before those on AS would need to or go that direction.

Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Based on the NCCN guidelines (PROS-1 ==> PROS-3 ==> PROS-C) you are a "Low" risk (T1-T2a, Gleason <=6, PSA < 10). For "Low" risk, NCCN says all three options (radiation, surgery, AS) are available (there is no mention of number of cores for "Low" risk, only "Very Low" risk). Except, they infer (my interpretation) on the AS page of the guidelines that AS (they actually state "Observation") is not preferred for >= 10 year life expectancy. Which would rule out AS for you IMHO. But it sounds like you already sorted this out. As has been stated, you have time and really should see a Radiation Oncologist. Others on here have successfully gone the radiation route at about your age. It doesn't hurt to get a consult. Good Luck! NCCN Guidelines (you may need to create a free account)

Posts.Title: Recent PCa diagnosis - Looking for some opinions

Posts.Content: Sounds like you are getting some good advice from your doc. Meeting with a Radiation Oncologist is certainly a good idea to better understand if radiation is an option for you. Samadi is certainly one of the top surgeons and one I considered in my list. The benefit with surgery is getting the post-surgical pathology report so you know how aggressive the cancer really is. Of course, you have the risks, but ask Samadi what his history has been with someone with your Dx in terms of getting the trifecta (no ED, no Incontinence and Cure) after surgery. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Forum unstable - Too many sticky's?

Posts.Content: ddayglo, you make an excellent point about Viagra (or Cialis and Viagra in my guess). My insurance only pays for 15 pills every 45 days. If I had known, I would have got the script earlier and stocked up. Also, hit up the doc for samples (push hard for extras), you may be surprised how many samples they have. Also the diet and exercise, I think, were a big part of my recovery. I started before surgery and at six weeks post surgery I started back up. I work out 4-5 days per week for 45-60 minutes. I use FitDay to track my calories and macros (protein, fat and carbs) every day. While not everyone can or will be this disciplined, any exercise and a little controlled food consumption (I hate the word "diet"... it still makes me cringe) can keep us older farts feeling a little younger.

Posts.Title: What I WISH I did BEFORE my Surgery...

Posts.Content: The problem is that there is no real definition of "classic and well defined Low-T". The level is measurable, but the symptoms (fatigue, libido, irritability, etc.) are very subjective and nearly impossible to quantify. And, for those of us that have seen benefits from TRT, you would have a very difficult time telling us to do something else. Of course, diet and exercise is another way to improve testosterone levels, but nutritionist and trainers are typically not covered by insurance...

Posts.Title: Psa undetectable 7 months post RP !!

Posts.Content: wishful, you should really consolidate all your posts to some degree and put your info in your signature in order to make it easier for folks to reply. Unfortunately, you have joined our club. Your biopsy appears to say you have Gleason 7 (3+4) with three cores positive with a max involvement of a core of 20%. The "High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia" or HGPIN looks like another read on that core or another from that area. It means they found tissue that may be a precursor to cancer, but cannot be called cancer. It does not mean that the cancer they found on the apex is "high grade"... your Gleason score is what is important. By NCCN guidelines you are Intermediate Risk. I would suggest that you have your slides sent out for a 2nd opinion to validate the scores. In some cases the scores are changed... and if changed down, then AS would be an option. Regardless, if the score remains 3+4, you are still in an excellent position for successful treatment (or even AS dependent on your age). What did your urologist recommend? Still no need to panic, you have time to think through this and what you want to do. Best of luck and keep us updated.

Posts.Title: What did you use for sitting after prostate surgery?

Posts.Content: Hi Bricks, Top right of the page, click settings, then signature on the left. I am a little confused on the total number of positive cores they found... is it 5 our of 12? Your PSA is high, but it appears that you had an infection and/or prostatis which yields high PSA. It is odd to me that a doc would say let's wait until a PSA of 20 versus 17... I have no answer for that. I would have expected that the doc would have expected the infection to still need treatment to see of the PSA drops. Regardless, you have cancer. You may want to have the slides sent for a second opinion by a lab that specializes in prostate cancer to validate the G6. It does appear that you have all the options open to you. I would recommend that you continue to get up to speed on the options. Also, if you are certain you want surgery, then start looking for a good surgeon (with hundreds, if not a thousand plus surgeries). It is worth meeting or talking with them whether you end up with surgery or not. It does not look like you need to rush... so take a breadth and recognize that your stats indicate that you likely have very treatable cancer. Keep asking questions!

Posts.Title: Herniated navel complications during surgery

Posts.Content: Hi GKM... as others have said, delaying treatment for several months should not be a problem (I waited 6 months without concern). It would be helpful to know: 1. Number of biopsy samples taken 2. For positive samples, percentage of involvement 3. PSA history 4. Any findings on a DRE (e.g., enlarged prostate, nodule found or not, etc... or normal) No need to provide these if you don't want to, it just helps some of the folks here with formulating thoughts and advice. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Need Help with Treatment Decision

Posts.Content: I struggle with the ultra-sensitive PSA tests... I mean, what are you going to do if your USPSA hits .1? It is not like you can get another biopsy and it would seem out of the norm that a doctor would recommend treatment. The treatment threshold is still typically .2 with >.1 being the concern level. IMHO it just adds another opportunity to worry about something that may be nothing. But, in the end, it is your body and if this information helps than go for it... just try to make some threshold decision points in advance so you know when you need to take action.

Posts.Title: PSA rising after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hey justdone, When I got my first catheter out I had a slow stream... and then it STOPPED all together (very painful). Had to get another catheter put back in for another week. After that I was putting out fires. Probably some remaining inflammation at the surgical site, but ask your doctor especially if you are retaining and having any pain due to the slow stream. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: small slow stream

Posts.Content: Hi Bow, As others have stated surgery was pretty much a breeze. I was up and walking the halls within a few hours after surgery. Walked around all night and was released the next day before noon. For me, the catheter was a non event... did not bother me in the least. Lidocaine and KY lube where the catheter went in a few times a day worked wonders. I had surgery during the winter in NY, so the leg bag had the added benefit of keeping my leg warm! Everyone's recovery is a bit unique and times vary for ED and Incontinence to return to "normal". I was lucky and had no incontinence issues and minor ED issues. The skill of the surgeon is probably the most important factor in recovery... one of the reasons I flew to NY to have it done. Check with your uro and get his thoughts on T after surgery... opinions vary widely. Personally, I have gone back on T but researched the heck out of it and for my particular scenario decided it was extremely low risk (my uro agreed). Good luck!

I have no answer for that. I would have expected that the doc would have expected the infection to still need treatment to see of the PSA drops. Regardless, you have cancer. You may want to have the slides sent for a second opinion by a lab that specializes in prostate cancer to validate the G6. It does appear that you have all the options open to you. I would recommend that you continue to get up to speed on the options. Also, if you are certain you want surgery, then start looking for a good surgeon (with hundreds, if not a thousand plus surgeries). It is worth meeting or talking with them whether you end up with surgery or not. It does not look like you need to rush... so take a breadth and recognize that your stats indicate that you likely have very treatable cancer. Keep asking questions!

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: RR, I applaud your purpose and that you wrote a book. But you have to look at it from the side of the folks that have been posting on this forum. Those that have read countless studies and articles and have freely given advice and thoughts to others. You come on the forum and within a few posts become defensive and authoritative while letting all know you wrote a book. You don't even put your stats in your signature, instead you promote your book. As a suggestion, it may have or is better to post in the stickies and refer to your concerns as "Side Effects to Ask About if Considering Surgery"... since you do bring up some very valid concerns and thoughts. Also, since you tend to point out the negatives it would be helpful to point out counter arguments and thoughts. Otherwise you have to be prepared for the onslaught of questions, criticism and counterpoints that the knowledgeable folks on this forum will provide. Finally, you authored a book and you posted on a public forum... you need to have a thicker skin... all authors are criticized at some point. The good ones roll with it and provide sound retorts or are will to concede that others are making valid points as well. IMHO

Posts.Content: You could consider all those. But without specific information about your situation (PSA history, age, DRE results, etc.) it is hard to give good feedback. Therefore, you might consider what your doctor suggests or get a 2nd opinion as suggested in your other thread. There are a few on here that have concerns over a biopsy (I am not one of them), but like all topics in life there are folks on the extreme ends. I would say most folks find them no big deal. Takes about 10 minutes for a 12 core sample and has some minor discomfort (pinch yourself with your fingernails 12 times).

Posts.Title: Brachytherrapy any advice

Posts.Content: Hello All... just got the news yesterday that I have PC. Good news is that it appears to have been found about as early as possible. I know I have time but I am looking at my options. Doc said the most probable options are AS or radiation. He told me it is really up to me and whether I can deal with knowing I have cancer while on AS. He also said to go talk with the folks at the radiation lab (he suggested a doc at SFRO) to get their input and what radiation technique would be best... so I will do this next week. The minor complication is that I have low testosterone and have been getting 100mg testosterone/wk IM and it had significantly improved my energy level, mood and libido. Since I am no longer taking it, the symptoms have returned. Doc said it is possible that given successful radiation I could look at going back on testosterone six months after completing radiation but no promises. Another minor factor is that I am currently between jobs so now would be a good time to get treatment as when I work I usually travel quite a bit. My wife is awesome and very understanding, but having low energy and libido is taxing on her and me. So I am a bit stuck... I am currently thinking that this would be the best plan: 1. Stop smoking 2. Lose some weight and improve diet 3. Exercise more (I certainly have the time) 4. AS for six months and re-access #4 could change to radiation based on my visit to the lab, but I am interested in your thoughts. Thanks!

Posts.Content: Thanks all for the quick response and Flkjr for responding first! I have already downloaded the book on Kindle and started highlighting parts to look at again... it is definitely a good source! ddayglo, thanks...I have read on this a other sites that it might be worthwhile to get another pathology read on the slides... doing some investigation to see where to go that specializes in reading for prostate cancer. ThatBiopsyHurt (I love the handle, though my biopsy was no worse than giving blood), I like the idea of another biopsy (being an engineer, the more data I have the more accurate the analysis)... guess I have to talk to the doc to see when that can be done. My wife is very involved and definitely wants to be with me during visits and meetings. fasteddie... thanks for the tip on keeping notes and data... I need to go back to the two docs I used to make sure I have all the test results... I'll do that Monday. Though I only show 2 PSA tests in my sig, I do know I had 4 and one of them was around 3.8... the only one less than 4 (but I think this was a different lab). Forums like this are a GREAT source of information and support... thanks to all and Good Luck and best wishes right back at all of you!

Posts.Content: Hi RTS... we are in a very similar position. I am still not sure what I am going to do, so I've defaulted to AS while I continue to research and listen/read what others on here have to say. Read up on Pat Walsh's book that Highlander recommends. My take from his book is that for someone in our age range he recommends surgery (but he is a surgeon) due to the amount of potential lifespan we have left. He does also say that AS is an option in other parts of his book so he contradicts himself in some regards... which is about what you will hear on this site. Read several of the threads on this site and you will also get a feel for the various arguments around AS and treatment. All of them are very good (though can be a little passionate at times and will give you a sense for what the risks and benefits are. In the end, as several docs have told me, you can't make a bad decision... just one you have to live with. If I go treatment, I have started moving more towards surgery versus radiation... but even that decision is hard to nail down (various pros and cons of each). I'll post some links to various sites I have used if you are interested. Good luck and I will stay tuned to your progress!

Posts.Content: It varies by doctor. But from experience, don't rush to take it out. I had mine out after 9 days (I was flying out the next day) and by the time I got home I could hardly pee. By the second day I was in SO much pain I had to go to the ER to have the cath put back in (never thought something like that could feel so good). I had over 900cc of urine in my bladder for 2 days. A week later my local uro took out the 2nd cath and I started knocking over soda cans at 6 feet.

Posts.Title: HELP Post Prostate Surgery

Posts.Content: The problem is that there is no real definition of "classic and well defined Low-T". The level is measurable, but the symptoms (fatigue, libido, irritability, etc.) are very subjective and nearly impossible to quantify. And, for those of us that have seen benefits from TRT, you would have a very difficult time telling us to do something else. Of course, diet and exercise is another way to improve testosterone levels, but nutritionist and trainers are typically not covered by insurance...

Posts.Title: New IYork Times article on Low-T therapy.

Posts.Content: Hey Jeff, you make an interesting point IF you know you only have 10 years to live. Problem is you really have no idea if you'll die tomorrow in some freak accident or die in 40 years from some jungle disease you got on a safari you decided to take on your bucket list. You can only attack, make decisions and try to control what you know and have the ability to influence. Today, you know you have prostate cancer. Make your decisions only on that fact and decide what you want to do about it... then do it. Don't get caught up in the "what if I have" and "I might die from" confusion, it has no bearing on what you actually know. Tomorrow, you can pick something else to make decisions about and then go make that happen. Before you know it, you won't have anything else to attack that might threaten your life... so more energy can go into things that make your life brighter and building great memories. Just my HO and worth the price charged. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: PSA in the 9's G6 ... more cancer later?

Posts.Content: wishful, you should really consolidate all your posts to some degree and put your info in your signature in order to make it easier for folks to reply. Unfortunately, you have joined our club. Your biopsy appears to say you have Gleason 7 (3+4) with three cores positive with a max involvement of a core of 20%. The "High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia" or HGPIN looks like another read on that core or another from that area. It means they found tissue that may be a precursor to cancer, but cannot be called cancer. It does not mean that the cancer they found on the apex is "high grade"... your Gleason score is what is important. By NCCN guidelines you are Intermediate Risk. I would suggest that you have your slides sent out for a 2nd opinion to validate the scores. In some cases the scores are changed... and if changed down, then AS would be an option. Regardless, if the score remains 3+4, you are still in an excellent position for successful treatment (or even AS dependent on your age). What did your urologist recommend? Still no need to panic, you have time to think through this and what you want to do. Best of luck and keep us updated.

Posts.Title: MRI results not good

Posts.Content: Sounds like you are getting some good advice from your doc. Meeting with a Radiation Oncologist is certainly a good idea to better understand if radiation is an option for you. Samadi is certainly one of the top surgeons and one I considered in my list. The benefit with surgery is getting the post-surgical pathology report so you know how aggressive the cancer really is. Of course, you have the risks, but ask Samadi what his history has been with someone with your Dx in terms of getting the trifecta (no ED, no Incontinence and Cure) after surgery. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Just Dx w/ gleason 4+3=7.

Posts.Content: I am currently back on testosterone. I've researched it pretty thoroughly and have come to the conclusion that T does provide some sort of fuel for PC. BUT, I also have come to believe that there is a saturation point that is pretty low (100-250) so anything above that does no harm. Having said that, I remember reading some studies that if you had an advanced stage of PC then the risk might be higher if you go on T after treatment. In any case, like the decision to treat or not, the decision to go on T is a personal choice that each individual should research and make a decision based on all factors including what is important for their quality of life. The "experts" have all kinds of varying opinions and the easy decision for them is to say stay off T. Do your own research. Also, don't be afraid to confront you doctors. When they say stay off... ask them why... what studies do they base their statement on? Many of them will stumble and mumble something about a 60 year old study where someone won a noble prize when the conclusion was based on one person... go figure.

Posts.Content: Hi L Eugene, Sorry to hear you have joined the club. You will find a great deal of information here from members who have pretty much seen it all and are more than willing to help and answer questions. What type of surgery are you having... e.g., open or robotic? I suggest you start by reading the stickies: What I wish I knew before my Da Vinci surgery What I Need to Know About ED What I Need to Know About Incontinence These threads have information in them about the surgery (most of it applies to any type of surgery) and the possible side effects. The surgery thread has info on the types of things you might need pre/post surgery. Also, it would be helpful to know if you are getting surgery locally or have to travel (e.g. by car for hours or plane). Take a look at those then ask any follow up questions you may have. Someone will have and answer or opinion. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Suggestions

Posts.Content: Hi Bricks, Top right of the page, click settings, then signature on the left. I am a little confused on the total number of positive cores they found... is it 5 our of 12? Your PSA is high, but it appears that you had an infection and/or prostatis which yields high PSA. It is odd to me that a doc would say let's wait until a PSA of 20 versus 17... I have no answer for that. I would have expected that the doc would have expected the infection to still need treatment to see of the PSA drops. Regardless, you have cancer. You may want to have the slides sent for a second opinion by a lab that specializes in prostate cancer to validate the G6. It does appear that you have all the options open to you. I would recommend that you continue to get up to speed on the options. Also, if you are certain you want surgery, then start looking for a good surgeon (with hundreds, if not a thousand plus surgeries). It is worth meeting or talking with them whether you end up with surgery or not. It does not look like you need to rush... so take a breadth and recognize that your stats indicate that you likely have very treatable cancer. Keep asking questions!

Posts.Content: I struggle with the ultra-sensitive PSA tests... I mean, what are you going to do if your USPSA hits .1? It is not like you can get another biopsy and it would seem out of the norm that a doctor would recommend treatment. The treatment threshold is still typically .2 with >.1 being the concern level. IMHO it just adds another opportunity to worry about something that may be nothing. But, in the end, it is your body and if this information helps than go for it... just try to make some threshold decision points in advance so you know when you need to take action.
