Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: wishful, you should really consolidate all your posts to some degree and put your info in your signature in order to make it easier for folks to reply. Unfortunately, you have joined our club. Your biopsy appears to say you have Gleason 7 (3+4) with three cores positive with a max involvement of a core of 20%. The "High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia" or HGPIN looks like another read on that core or another from that area. It means they found tissue that may be a precursor to cancer, but cannot be called cancer. It does not mean that the cancer they found on the apex is "high grade"... your Gleason score is what is important. By NCCN guidelines you are Intermediate Risk. I would suggest that you have your slides sent out for a 2nd opinion to validate the scores. In some cases the scores are changed... and if changed down, then AS would be an option. Regardless, if the score remains 3+4, you are still in an excellent position for successful treatment (or even AS dependent on your age). What did your urologist recommend? Still no need to panic, you have time to think through this and what you want to do. Best of luck and keep us updated.

Good Luck!

Posts.Content: RR, I applaud your purpose and that you wrote a book. But you have to look at it from the side of the folks that have been posting on this forum. Those that have read countless studies and articles and have freely given advice and thoughts to others. You come on the forum and within a few posts become defensive and authoritative while letting all know you wrote a book. You don't even put your stats in your signature, instead you promote your book. As a suggestion, it may have or is better to post in the stickies and refer to your concerns as "Side Effects to Ask About if Considering Surgery"... since you do bring up some very valid concerns and thoughts. Also, since you tend to point out the negatives it would be helpful to point out counter arguments and thoughts. Otherwise you have to be prepared for the onslaught of questions, criticism and counterpoints that the knowledgeable folks on this forum will provide. Finally, you authored a book and you posted on a public forum... you need to have a thicker skin... all authors are criticized at some point. Posts.Title: question about clear liquid diet

Posts.Content: Hi Bow, As others have stated surgery was pretty much a breeze. I was up and walking the halls within a few hours after surgery. Walked around all night and was released the next day before noon. For me, the catheter was a non event... did not bother me in the least. Lidocaine and KY lube where the catheter went in a few times a day worked wonders. I had surgery during the winter in NY, so the leg bag had the added benefit of keeping my leg warm! Everyone's recovery is a bit unique and times vary for ED and Incontinence to return to "normal". I was lucky and had no incontinence issues and minor ED issues. The skill of the surgeon is probably the most important factor in recovery... one of the reasons I flew to NY to have it done. Check with your uro and get his thoughts on T after surgery... opinions vary widely. Personally, I have gone back on T but researched the heck out of it and for my particular scenario decided it was extremely low risk (my uro agreed). Good luck!

Posts.Content: You could consider all those. But without specific information about your situation (PSA history, age, DRE results, etc.) it is hard to give good feedback. Therefore, you might consider what your doctor suggests or get a 2nd opinion as suggested in your other thread. There are a few on here that have concerns over a biopsy (I am not one of them), but like all topics in life there are folks on the extreme ends. I would say most folks find them no big deal. Takes about 10 minutes for a 12 core sample and has some minor discomfort (pinch yourself with your fingernails 12 times).

If you have not tried injections, then I think you should talk to your doc about getting them. Here is a little book about injections that mentions they work without the nerves. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: ED with both nerves removed.

Posts.Content: Hi RTS... we are in a very similar position. I am still not sure what I am going to do, so I've defaulted to AS while I continue to research and listen/read what others on here have to say. Read up on Pat Walsh's book that Highlander recommends. My take from his book is that for someone in our age range he recommends surgery (but he is a surgeon) due to the amount of potential lifespan we have left. He does also say that AS is an option in other parts of his book so he contradicts himself in some regards... which is about what you will hear on this site. Read several of the threads on this site and you will also get a feel for the various arguments around AS and treatment. All of them are very good (though can be a little passionate at times and will give you a sense for what the risks and benefits are. In the end, as several docs have told me, you can't make a bad decision... just one you have to live with. If I go treatment, I have started moving more towards surgery versus radiation... but even that decision is hard to nail down (various pros and cons of each). I'll post some links to various sites I have used if you are interested. Good luck and I will stay tuned to your progress!

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Hello All... just got the news yesterday that I have PC. Good news is that it appears to have been found about as early as possible. I know I have time but I am looking at my options. Doc said the most probable options are AS or radiation. He told me it is really up to me and whether I can deal with knowing I have cancer while on AS. He also said to go talk with the folks at the radiation lab (he suggested a doc at SFRO) to get their input and what radiation technique would be best... so I will do this next week. The minor complication is that I have low testosterone and have been getting 100mg testosterone/wk IM and it had significantly improved my energy level, mood and libido. Since I am no longer taking it, the symptoms have returned. Doc said it is possible that given successful radiation I could look at going back on testosterone six months after completing radiation but no promises. Another minor factor is that I am currently between jobs so now would be a good time to get treatment as when I work I usually travel quite a bit. My wife is awesome and very understanding, but having low energy and libido is taxing on her and me. So I am a bit stuck... I am currently thinking that this would be the best plan: 1. Stop smoking 2. Lose some weight and improve diet 3. Exercise more (I certainly have the time) 4. AS for six months and re-access #4 could change to radiation based on my visit to the lab, but I am interested in your thoughts. Thanks!

Posts.Content: Thanks all for the quick response and Flkjr for responding first! I have already downloaded the book on Kindle and started highlighting parts to look at again... it is definitely a good source! ddayglo, thanks...I have read on this a other sites that it might be worthwhile to get another pathology read on the slides... doing some investigation to see where to go that specializes in reading for prostate cancer. ThatBiopsyHurt (I love the handle, though my biopsy was no worse than giving blood), I like the idea of another biopsy (being an engineer, the more data I have the more accurate the analysis)... guess I have to talk to the doc to see when that can be done. My wife is very involved and definitely wants to be with me during visits and meetings. fasteddie... thanks for the tip on keeping notes and data... I need to go back to the two docs I used to make sure I have all the test results... I'll do that Monday. Though I only show 2 PSA tests in my sig, I do know I had 4 and one of them was around 3.8... the only one less than 4 (but I think this was a different lab). Forums like this are a GREAT source of information and support... thanks to all and Good Luck and best wishes right back at all of you!

Posts.Title: Pain with erections

Posts.Content: RR, I applaud your purpose and that you wrote a book. But you have to look at it from the side of the folks that have been posting on this forum. Those that have read countless studies and articles and have freely given advice and thoughts to others. You come on the forum and within a few posts become defensive and authoritative while letting all know you wrote a book. You don't even put your stats in your signature, instead you promote your book. As a suggestion, it may have or is better to post in the stickies and refer to your concerns as "Side Effects to Ask About if Considering Surgery"... since you do bring up some very valid concerns and thoughts. Also, since you tend to point out the negatives it would be helpful to point out counter arguments and thoughts. Otherwise you have to be prepared for the onslaught of questions, criticism and counterpoints that the knowledgeable folks on this forum will provide. Finally, you authored a book and you posted on a public forum... you need to have a thicker skin... all authors are criticized at some point. The good ones roll with it and provide sound retorts or are will to concede that others are making valid points as well. IMHO

Posts.Content: Others will chime in, but "undetectable" means, for the most part, Zero. Not until it raises to .2 is the flag typically raised. Good article by John Hopkins here. The doctor mentioning that some cells could be left behind is just covering himself, IMHO. So in your dad's case... all is good! My thoughts are it is time to put this in the past and keep getting the PSA tests (like the rest of us are doing) and move along with life. Best Wishes!

Posts.Content: I'm sorry to hear that you and your husband have joined our club, but you are in good hands with the folks here. I think before most folks can really provide helpful insight, we need a little more information on the biobsy (e.g., # of positive cores and Gleason score on those cores). Also his PSA history would be helpful. Getting a second opinion on the biopsy will probably be helpful and usually recommended by most folks here. You can read up on Staging here. This is a decent link with info and questions. Others will chime in with their thoughts. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: I got most of this from some other post on the forum, but it is the list of questions I asked my docs... Questions about the doctor:  How many procedures have you performed?  How many do you do per day?  How many patients have you treated who are my age?  Will you personally be operating the console for the entire surgery?  Are there any other surgeons in the room (e.g., interns) and what is the role of the other surgeons in the room during the surgery? Questions about my preparation:  Are there other tests that I should have to determine the exact size, location, and aggressiveness of the cancer (e.g., MRI, CT, etc.)?  What can I be doing TODAY to prepare my body for the surgery and to reduce side effects? (Kegel exercises? How much is too much? Exercises?)  If I decided this week, when would we do the surgery? Questions about the surgery:  Explain the procedure pre op, op and post op.  What may be removed other than the prostate itself (nodes, etc)? How and when will you decide what to remove?  Will you attempt to preserve the internal (top)/external (bottom) sphincter urethra muscles?  Does the size of the prostate have any influence on the difficulty of the surgery less or my body post op?  How will you manipulate/remove the prostate using the robotic tools without tearing the capsule (possibly causing cancer cells to be "spilled" inside my body)?  What will you do to spare the nerves around the prostate?  How is bleeding controlled?  How many openings will you need to make for the robotic components?  Is the size of the incision above the belly button related to the size of the prostate?  How big of an incision should I expect?  How will the incision be closed? I have heard of people who have had their incision become herniated after a few months. When will the stitches/staples/etc be removed?  How are the loose ends of the vas deferens closed? If there are clips applied, what material are they made of any how do you ensure that they never open?  Will the surgery involve changes to my bladder capacity?  Will you do the entire surgery? Questions about the outcome:  What are the outcomes of your patients that are my age (cancer cure, incontinence, ED)?  How about these side effects over time, i.e. quality of life 2-3, 5-10, 15+ years out?  I have heard reports of penis size reductions that have occurred due to prostatectomy. Is that true, and what will be done to prevent/minimize it?  What tests/monitoring will be necessary to track whether the cancer returns (in the prostate or elsewhere nearby)?  How soon after the surgery will I get the pathology report?  If the cancer returns, what's next? Questions about recovery:  How long should I expect to need a catheter?  What role does your staff play in my post op recovery?  Since I will be traveling, how is post op follow up performed?  What rehabilitation strategies will I use after the surgery to minimize incontinence/ED? (Daily 25mg of Viagra? Vacuum pump?)  How soon can I return to work?  How soon can I return to my regular daily workout regimen (aerobic/weights/cycling)?  How soon can I return to sexual activity?  When would you want to do the first post-surgery PSA test, and what would you expect for results?  What is your role vs. my urologists' role in my recovery and care: 1) treating side effects from the surgery; 2) long-term monitoring for cancer recurrence Other:  I'm told that if I have radiation as my primary treatment, that surgery is still an option as a salvage therapy. Do you agree?  Will you be available to me via phone and/or email for the first week or two after the surgery?

I think before most folks can really provide helpful insight, we need a little more information on the biobsy (e.g., # of positive cores and Gleason score on those cores). Also his PSA history would be helpful. Getting a second opinion on the biopsy will probably be helpful and usually recommended by most folks here. You can read up on Staging here. This is a decent link with info and questions. Others will chime in with their thoughts. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: I actually wore the leg bag all the time except for going to bed. Never had a problem and I rarely knew it was there. I wore it high up on my thigh and it was connected directly to the catheter with no extensions. This is the one I was using. It was easy to tell when it was getting full (just reach down an put my hand on it) and it was easy to drain. I almost always wore sweat pants or loose jeans. Could just go to the toilet, raise my pant leg and open the valve while standing. When I showered, I would just let the catheter dangle and rinse the bag out with the running shower water before putting it back on when I got out of the shower.

Posts.Title: RALP after Saturation Biopsy

Posts.Content: Sounds like you covered all the basis. After your first post I was ready to say that AS may be an option, but you did a smart follow up and it looks like treatment is in order. As Chuck said, look into the various types... either radiation or RALP is a good option. As far as nerve sparing after multiple biopsies... I talked to three different surgeons and all of them said it makes nerve sparring more difficult for the reasons your doctor described. But it is not impossible and an important fact for the surgeon to know before starting. You might ask your surgeon how many times he has seen this and what is his success rate for nerve sparring. I think it is important to know that you have the best possible surgeon (should you go that route) for the condition you have. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: Hi Fastball, You have a very good chance of getting successful treatment. Did your doc feel anything when (s)he did a DRE? Take some time and do the research on various treatments (different types of radiation and surgery). Based on your stats, treatment is in order. Did the report say that they found cancer on both sides of the prostate? This and the previous question help determine the stage. Feel free to ask away with any specific questions and someone will certainly respond. Good Luck and keep us updated!

Posts.Content: Hey Bob... talk to your doctor. 40mg a day does seem like a lot. I am on 5mg a day and my doctor prescribed Viagra when I think I need it. He said to take 100mg of Viagra on days when I think I need the extra... well stiffness, but not to abuse it (e.g., maybe once per week or so).

Posts.Title: Brachytherapy and cialis

Posts.Content: Pratoman... IMHO, you are over analyzing (though must of us probably have done the same). Folks go to JH for the exact reason you did and you got GOOD news. As far as you now know, you are a 3 core G6... those are the current facts. The last person most folks would question is Epstein. If you go surgery, then there is a good chance the doctor will want to do his own read of the slides (Tewari did). Since you seemed to have decided treatment, and there is nothing much you can do about what you have, you should focus on selecting a treatment and surgeon or RO. Having said all that, I think everyone hear completely understands and is sympathetic to where you are at... but you have time and things will get/feel better once once you get past the selection process. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Hi Walnut, The dilemma here is that you don't know if you have cancer. But you could certainly have it, but then the question is how aggressive is it? It sounds like your visit to the doctor sent you down a bit of an emotional path to prove him wrong... trust me, I know the feeling. But what if you do have cancer? The only real way to get a chance of knowing if you do and how bad it might be is to have a biopsy. Really the biopsy should be an easy decision for you IMHO... without it, you just don't know. Of course you could just continue to monitor your PSA and hope that the nodule is nothing and if you have cancer it is not aggressive...

Posts.Title: Decisions, Decisions......

Posts.Content: Good question. It's been awhile since I've read up on it but I seem to remember saturation biopsies can be don first when an imaging technique or DRE may have indicated an increased chance of cancer (and location). It seems logical that after one biopsy, a second one can be more targeted based on the results of the first. Typical number of cores I have seen range from 20 to 40. Forgive me if you've posted this elsewhere, but what was the result of your last biopsy?

Posts.Title: Saturation Biopsy, how many cores taken

Posts.Content: It depends on what they find with the biopsy. If the biopsy is clean then good for your husband and the doc may suggest to retest PSA in 6 months or a year. If the biopsy comes back positive for PC, then there is a whole other discussion based on what is found. I might have missed it, but is your husband getting the biopsy or are you looking to see if he should forego it? Personally, I think he should get the biopsy. It's pretty safe (I think going to the dentist can be riskier), quick and relatively painless. He is same age as I was with similar PSA numbers. It turns out I had PC, but I had more information and could decide what to do about it (treatment or AS). As far as "over diagnosis and over treatment"... pardon me, but who cares? There are a bazillion (OK, I am exaggerating) opinions on this topic that generalize a population and I was not part of the general population... this was about me. Your husband needs to make the best decision for him and his situation. BTW, what are your husbands thoughts on this? Good Luck!

Posts.Title: PC Risk, PSA and Biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Walnut, The dilemma here is that you don't know if you have cancer. But you could certainly have it, but then the question is how aggressive is it? It sounds like your visit to the doctor sent you down a bit of an emotional path to prove him wrong... trust me, I know the feeling. But what if you do have cancer? The only real way to get a chance of knowing if you do and how bad it might be is to have a biopsy. Really the biopsy should be an easy decision for you IMHO... without it, you just don't know. Of course you could just continue to monitor your PSA and hope that the nodule is nothing and if you have cancer it is not aggressive...

Posts.Title: Reality check...

Posts.Content: Pratoman... IMHO, you are over analyzing (though must of us probably have done the same). Folks go to JH for the exact reason you did and you got GOOD news. As far as you now know, you are a 3 core G6... those are the current facts. The last person most folks would question is Epstein. If you go surgery, then there is a good chance the doctor will want to do his own read of the slides (Tewari did). Since you seemed to have decided treatment, and there is nothing much you can do about what you have, you should focus on selecting a treatment and surgeon or RO. Having said all that, I think everyone hear completely understands and is sympathetic to where you are at... but you have time and things will get/feel better once once you get past the selection process. Good Luck!

Posts.Title: Exercise Bicycle

Posts.Content: Excellent post Walnut... but I tend to think of it as pretty simple, not complicated. The Pelvic Floor Muscle is just that, a muscle... just like any other muscle it needs exercise. The more you exercise it, the stronger it will become and it's endurance will increase. More importantly you will get muscle memory. Muscle memory is not stored in your muscle, but in your brain (motor learning). It allows for involuntary muscle reaction to known situations. Based on my research, the jury is out on "over training" this muscle. Since the important part is muscle memory, the more training you do the more likely it is to take place. Now, having said that. If you want to strengthen the muscle then you need to train it hard and then let it rest. Like any other muscle, the strength and size happens during these periods of rest. So, in this case, you can over exercise. For instance, when I train a muscle group I lift heavy for about 45 minutes. Then I let it rest for 4-5 days before training that muscle group again. Smaller muscles (like the pelvic floor muscle) can be trained more often. Since your urethra passes through the Pelvic Floor Muscle, this muscle have excellent muscle memory, endurance and strength... in that order. This is why Kegel exercises are so important. The number you do helps with endurance and memory. The length you hold them helps with strength. My advice is to group all your exercises that affect this muscle so that you do them all together then rest. Since walking and biking are endurance and longer training periods I would do one or the other after doing Kegels. Do 15 minutes of Kegels and make them very difficult (squeeze as hard as you can for as long as you can). Then skip a day and do it again. I am no doctor but muscle training is a pretty well understood process. All of this, of course, is IMHO.

Posts.Title: Question on soreness after operation

Posts.Content: As Gman says, get some Lidocaine and also pick up some KY Lube. Put both on the tip of the penis around the catheter (Lidocaine first). I used a q-tip to put the Lidocain on and just dripped the KY on. The Lidocaine will help dull the pain and the KY will help lube the catheter to move in and out. I put it on about 4-5 times a day. Between the two of these, I had no discomfort with the catheter. Also, make sure the tube has enough slack in it for movement so that it is not constantly tugging.
